name: electrolysis of magnesium chloride, from zirconium sponge production | chlorine, for reuse in zirconium and hafnium tetrachloride production | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/25620/documentation

This dataset models the electrolysis of 1 kg of magnesium chloride produced during the production of zirconium sponge using the Kroll process, which is modelled by the following reaction: ZrCl4+ 2Mg → Zr + 2MgCl2. The electrolysis of magnesium chloride separates the magnesium from the chlorine through the following reaction: MgCl2 → Mg + Cl2. The recovered magnesium is fed back to the reduction and distillation process (which produces zirconium sponge) and the chlorine is fed back to the carbochlorination process of zircon (which produces zirconium tetrachloride bundled with hafnium).;Based on stoichiometry, 2.0874 kg of magnesium chloride is produced as a byproduct per kg of produced Zr sponge. Because 0.0484 kg of MgCl2 is lost in the reduction and distillation step, 2.0386 kg of MgCl2 per kg Zr sponge are sent to electrolysis (for more information consult the exchange comments of the exchanges ''inert waste'' and ''magnesium chloride, from zirconium sponge production'' of the dataset ''zirconium sponge production, from zirconium tetrachloride, FR'').;Due to absence of data, the electrolysis process of magnesium chloride after the production of 1 kg of zirconium sponge was approximated with the electrolysis process of magnesium chloride after the production of 1 kg of titanium sponge (consult dataset ''electrolysis of magnesium chloride, from titanium sponge production'' available in version 3.8 of Ecoinvent).This approximation is considered acceptable, as the treatment of magnesium chloride through electrolysis is assumed to be independent of the origin of magnesium chloride. Therefore, all the reported assumptions from the previously mentioned dataset apply also to this one. The aforementioned dataset was based on the Gao et al. (2018) publication.;Reference: Gao, F., Nie, Z., Yang, D., Sun, B., Liu, Y., Gong, X., & Wang, Z. (2018). Environmental impacts analysis of titanium sponge production using Kroll process in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 174, 771-779. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.09.240.

The activity starts with the reception of magnesium chloride, obtained from the production of zirconium sponge using the Kroll process.

The activity ends with the recovery of magnesium and chlorine. Infrastructure use is not included as this process is assumed to take place in the same facility as zirconium sponge production.
category: C:Manufacturing/24:Manufacture of basic metals/242:Manufacture of basic precious and other non-ferrous metals/2420:Manufacture of basic precious and other non-ferrous metals

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Data are considered representative of current production practices. The data are assumed to be valid on average for 5 years after the publication of that article.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Dataset valid for the entire corresponding region.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The reduction and distillation step of the Kroll process produces zirconium sponge and magnesium chloride as a byproduct based on the following stoichiometric equation: ZrCl4+ 2Mg → Zr + 2MgCl2. Based on stoichiometry, 0.53286 kg of magnesium are required as an input per kg of Zr Sponge and 2.0874 kg of magnesium chloride is produced as a byproduct per kg of produced Zr sponge. Because 0.0484 kg of MgCl2 is lost in the reduction and distillation step, 2.0386 kg of MgCl2 per kg Zr sponge are sent to electrolysis.;;The magnesium chloride is then separated via electrolysis in order to recover the magnesium and chlorine through the following reaction: MgCl2 → Mg + Cl2. After refining, the magnesium is recycled and serves again as input to the reduction and distillation process, during which zirconium sponge is produced, while chlorine (after it is filtrated and purified) is recycled and sent back to the carbochlorination process as an input.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Approximation of the electrolysis process of magnesium chloride after the production of 1 kg of zirconium sponge with the electrolysis process of magnesium chloride after the production of 1 kg of titanium sponge (consult dataset ''electrolysis of magnesium chloride, from titanium sponge production'' available in version 3.8 of Ecoinvent).This approximation is considered acceptable, as the treatment of magnesium chloride through electrolysis is assumed to be independent of the origin of magnesium chloride.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
Due to absence of data, all data regarding the electrolysis process were taken from the dataset ''electrolysis of magnesium chloride, from titanium sponge production, GLO'' as found in Ecoinvent version 3.8, which deals with the electrolysis of magnesium chloride (MgCl2 → Mg + Cl2) produced as a byproduct from the titanium sponge production process (TiCl4+ 2Mg → Ti + 2MgCl2 - same process used for the production of zirconium sponge). The previously mentioned dataset was based on the Gao et al. (2018) publication.

Reference: Gao, F., Nie, Z., Yang, D., Sun, B., Liu, Y., Gong, X., & Wang, Z. (2018). Environmental impacts analysis of titanium sponge production using Kroll process in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 174, 771-779. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.09.240.

exchanges.description:
This exchange represents the chlorine obtained from the electrolysis of 1 kg of magnesium chloride. This chlorine is recycled back to the zirconium and hafnium tetrachloride production process.

The electrolysis process of magnesium chloride after the production of 1 kg of zirconium sponge was approximated with the electrolysis process of magnesium chloride after the production of 1 kg of titanium sponge (consult ''electrolysis of magnesium chloride, from titanium sponge production'' available in version 3.8 of Ecoinvent).This approximation is considered acceptable, as the treatment of magnesium chloride through electrolysis is assumed to be independent of the origin of magnesium chloride. Consequently, the value for the recycled chlorine, was taken from the abovementioned dataset. 

The original description from the dataset is the following: 

[Value calculated based on value given in table 2 (column "Electrolysis of MgCl2") in Gao et al. (2018). According to that table, the chlorination step (2TiO2 + 4Cl2 + 3C → 2TiCl4 + 2CO + CO2) requires 1620 kg of chlorine per metric ton of titanium sponge to compensate for the chlorine that is not recovered by the electrolysis of magnesium chloride. Based on stoichiometry, roughly 2962 kg of Cl2 are required to produce 1 metric ton of titanium sponge. This means the overall recovery rate of Cl is roughly 45%. Because 0.093 kg of MgCl2 is lost in the reduction and distillation step, this means that 3.885 kg of MgCl2 per kg Ti are sent to electrolysis, out of which 1.342 kg of Cl are recovered. The amount of Cl recovered per kg of MgCl2 entering the electrolysis step is therefore roughly 0.345 kg and corresponds to a recovery rate of 46% in this step. 

Reference: Gao, F., Nie, Z., Yang, D., Sun, B., Liu, Y., Gong, X., & Wang, Z. (2018). Environmental impacts analysis of titanium sponge production using Kroll process in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 174, 771-779. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.09.240.]

exchanges.description: Since this activity represents the treatment of magnesium chloride, which is produced during the production of zirconium sponge, the reference product (magnesium chloride) has a negative sign. The negative sign indicates that the treatment activity (electrolysis) supplies the service of treating magnesium chloride (i.e the magnesium chloride is an input to the electrolysis process).

exchanges.description:
This exchange represents the electricity required as input during the electrolysis of 1 kg of magnesium chloride. 

The electrolysis process of magnesium chloride after the production of 1 kg of zirconium sponge was approximated with the electrolysis process of magnesium chloride after the production of 1 kg of titanium sponge (consult ''electrolysis of magnesium chloride, from titanium sponge production'' available in version 3.8 of Ecoinvent).This approximation is considered acceptable, as the treatment of magnesium chloride through electrolysis is assumed to be independent of the origin of magnesium chloride. Consequently, the value for electricity consumption, was taken from the abovementioned dataset. 

The original description from the dataset is the following: 

[Value from Table 2 (column "Electrolysis of MgCl2") in Gao et al. (2018). The amount of electricity consumed in the electrolysis process is 1.45E+04 kWh per metric ton of titanium sponge. This value was adjusted considering that for 1 kg of titanium sponge produced, 3.885 kg of MgCl2 is sent to the electrolysis step. 

Reference: Gao, F., Nie, Z., Yang, D., Sun, B., Liu, Y., Gong, X., & Wang, Z. (2018). Environmental impacts analysis of titanium sponge production using Kroll process in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 174, 771-779. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.09.240.]

exchanges.description:
This exchange represents the hydrogen fluoride emissions during the electrolysis of 1 kg of magnesium chloride. 

The electrolysis process of magnesium chloride after the production of 1 kg of zirconium sponge was approximated with the electrolysis process of magnesium chloride after the production of 1 kg of titanium sponge (consult ''electrolysis of magnesium chloride, from titanium sponge production'' available in version 3.8 of Ecoinvent).This approximation is considered acceptable, as the treatment of magnesium chloride through electrolysis is assumed to be independent of the origin of magnesium chloride. Consequently, the value for the hydrogen fluoride emissions, was taken from the abovementioned dataset. 

The original description from the dataset is the following: 

[Value from Table 2 (column "Electrolysis of MgCl2") in Gao et al. (2018). An emission of HF is reported to occur in the electrolysis process. It is assumed to be an emission to air. The reported amount is 6.36E-01 kg per metric ton of titanium sponge. This value was adjusted considering that for 1 kg of titanium sponge produced, 3.885 kg of MgCl2 is sent to the electrolysis step. 

Reference: Gao, F., Nie, Z., Yang, D., Sun, B., Liu, Y., Gong, X., & Wang, Z. (2018). Environmental impacts analysis of titanium sponge production using Kroll process in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 174, 771-779. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.09.240.]

The electrolysis process of magnesium chloride after the production of 1 kg of zirconium sponge was approximated with the electrolysis process of magnesium chloride after the production of 1 kg of titanium sponge (consult ''electrolysis of magnesium chloride, from titanium sponge production'' available in version 3.8 of Ecoinvent).This approximation is considered acceptable, as the treatment of magnesium chloride through electrolysis is assumed to be independent of the origin of magnesium chloride. Consequently, the value for electricity consumption, was taken from the abovementioned dataset. 

The original description from the dataset is the following: 

[Value from Table 2 (column "Electrolysis of MgCl2") in Gao et al. (2018). The amount of electricity consumed in the electrolysis process is 1.45E+04 kWh per metric ton of titanium sponge. This value was adjusted considering that for 1 kg of titanium sponge produced, 3.885 kg of MgCl2 is sent to the electrolysis step. 

Reference: Gao, F., Nie, Z., Yang, D., Sun, B., Liu, Y., Gong, X., & Wang, Z. (2018). Environmental impacts analysis of titanium sponge production using Kroll process in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 174, 771-779. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.09.240.]

exchanges.description:
This exchange represents the inert waste produced as a byproduct during the electrolysis of 1 kg of magnesium chloride. 

The amount of inert waste is calculated such that the mass of the inputs is equal to the mass of the outputs. According to Table 2 (column "Electrolysis of MgCl2") in Gao et al. (2018), 1.62E-01 kg of "other residue" (approximated here as inert waste) is produced in the electrolysis step per metric ton of titanium sponge. However, neither this amount nor the amount reported in the reduction and distillation step are large enough to account for the amounts of magnesium and chlorine that are not recovered by the electrolysis of MgCl2. Therefore, the amount of inert waste is calculated such that the mass of the inputs is equal to the mass of the outputs.

Reference: Gao, F., Nie, Z., Yang, D., Sun, B., Liu, Y., Gong, X., & Wang, Z. (2018). Environmental impacts analysis of titanium sponge production using Kroll process in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 174, 771-779. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.09.240.

exchanges.description:
This exchange represents the hydrogen chloride emissions during the electrolysis of 1 kg of magnesium chloride. 

The electrolysis process of magnesium chloride after the production of 1 kg of zirconium sponge was approximated with the electrolysis process of magnesium chloride after the production of 1 kg of titanium sponge (consult ''electrolysis of magnesium chloride, from titanium sponge production'' available in version 3.8 of Ecoinvent).This approximation is considered acceptable, as the treatment of magnesium chloride through electrolysis is assumed to be independent of the origin of magnesium chloride. Consequently, the value for the hydrogen chloride emissions, was taken from the abovementioned dataset. 

The original description from the dataset is the following: 

[Value from Table 2 (column "Electrolysis of MgCl2") in Gao et al. (2018). An emission of HCl is reported to occur in the electrolysis process. It is assumed to be an emission to air. The reported amount is 3.92 kg per metric ton of titanium sponge. This value was adjusted considering that for 1 kg of titanium sponge produced, 3.885 kg of MgCl2 is sent to the electrolysis step. 

Reference: Gao, F., Nie, Z., Yang, D., Sun, B., Liu, Y., Gong, X., & Wang, Z. (2018). Environmental impacts analysis of titanium sponge production using Kroll process in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 174, 771-779. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.09.240]

exchanges.description:
This exchange represents the electricity required as input during the electrolysis of 1 kg of magnesium chloride. 

The electrolysis process of magnesium chloride after the production of 1 kg of zirconium sponge was approximated with the electrolysis process of magnesium chloride after the production of 1 kg of titanium sponge (consult ''electrolysis of magnesium chloride, from titanium sponge production'' available in version 3.8 of Ecoinvent).This approximation is considered acceptable, as the treatment of magnesium chloride through electrolysis is assumed to be independent of the origin of magnesium chloride. Consequently, the value for electricity consumption, was taken from the abovementioned dataset. 

The original description from the dataset is the following: 

[Value from Table 2 (column "Electrolysis of MgCl2") in Gao et al. (2018). The amount of electricity consumed in the electrolysis process is 1.45E+04 kWh per metric ton of titanium sponge. This value was adjusted considering that for 1 kg of titanium sponge produced, 3.885 kg of MgCl2 is sent to the electrolysis step. 

Reference: Gao, F., Nie, Z., Yang, D., Sun, B., Liu, Y., Gong, X., & Wang, Z. (2018). Environmental impacts analysis of titanium sponge production using Kroll process in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 174, 771-779. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.09.240.]
